security_audit.summary: This skill is pure documentation in markdown format. It only contains linting command examples and descriptions. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, no environment variable reads, and no command execution capabilities. The skill describes what commands users can run but does not execute them.

content.value_statement: Code quality varies across projects and team members. This skill provides standardized linting commands for TypeScript and Python that you can customize and run consistently across your codebase.
actual_capabilities: Run Biome or ESLint for TypeScript and JavaScript linting
Execute Ruff for Python linting and formatting
Perform type checking with tsc --noEmit or mypy
Auto-fix common lint issues with --apply or --fix flags
limitations: Requires project to have linting tools installed (biome, ruff, eslint, mypy)
Only documents commands - does not install or configure linting tools
Does not modify files directly - users run commands manually
Exit codes are interpreted by the calling environment

faq.question: Which linter should I use for TypeScript?
faq.answer: Biome is recommended for speed. ESLint is also popular and has more plugins.

faq.question: What Python linter does this skill support?
faq.answer: Ruff is the recommended linter. It is 10-100x faster than traditional tools.

faq.question: How do I integrate lint with my test suite?
faq.answer: Run lint first, then type check, then tests. The skill shows this sequence in the self-test integration section.

faq.question: Is my data safe when running these commands?
faq.answer: Yes. Linting tools only read files locally. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: What do exit codes mean?
faq.answer: Exit code 0 means no issues. Exit code 1 means issues were found.

faq.question: How is this different from running lint directly?
faq.answer: This skill provides a curated list of commands customized for your project. It documents best practices and tool options.
